awd_titl_txt: Quantitative Biosensing at the Single-Molecule Level
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Joel M. Harris and his students at the University of Utah to develop new microscopy methods to help understand and optimize sensors for ultrasensitive detection of target biomolecules, including DNA and proteins.  These goals are being addressed through the quantitative imaging of individual molecules.  Single-molecule fluorescence imaging can provide absolute coverage information of both binding sites and bound target molecules on a biosensor surface. This technique represents quantitative analysis at the ultimate limit of counting individual molecules.  It is first being applied to studies of peptide binding to lipid bilayers that is relevant to cell signaling and to the behavior of proteins at biosensor surfaces.  Quantitative single-molecule imaging is also being adapted to measuring DNA hybridization, which forms the basis of genetic testing and gene-chip applications.  The influence of electrostatic interactions on DNA binding is being studied in order to understand how ionic strength acts at controlling variability in DNA sensor applications.  Single-molecule imaging can also serve as an analytical method, where counting individual bound DNA molecules on a capture surface enables detection of extremely low concentrations of target DNA in biological specimens. 
 
The program is assembling new instrumentation capable of imaging single molecules and data analysis methods for quantitative detection of molecules in the images.  This research will provide routes to new understanding of structural factors that influence the performance of biosensors that are used to detect disease and toxins.  The research also advances fundamental understanding of protein-membrane interactions and DNA hybridization kinetics, which are critical to development of new pharmaceuticals and biotechnologies.  The research provides multidisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in spectroscopy, microscopy, and bioanalytical chemistry and supports several collaborations with other research groups.  The project also impacts K-12 science education and public awareness through development of microscopy exercises and their deployment in classrooms of a Title I elementary school in Salt Lake City.

por.por_cntn:
This research project has been to develop new microscopy methods to help understand and optimize sensors for ultrasensitive detection of target biomolecules, including DNA and proteins.  These goals were addressed through the imaging and counting of individual molecules.  Single-molecule fluorescence imaging can provide absolute coverage information of both binding sites, used to attract target molecules from solution, and the target molecules themselves as they bind to a biosensor surface. This technique represents quantitative chemical analysis at the ultimate limit of counting individual molecules.  Quantitative single-molecule imaging was adapted to measuring DNA hybridization, a chemical reaction that forms the basis of DNA replication, genetic testing, and gene-chip applications.  Accurate knowledge of the rates of complementary DNA hybridization is integral to the design and understanding of DNA-based biosensors.  Single-molecule fluorescence imaging was applied to measuring rates of the reaction between target DNA and complementary probe DNA immobilized on glass surfaces.  The capture surface must be highly selective to avoid the influence of non-specific adsorption of non-complementary strands on the interpretation of single-molecule imaging results. This was accomplished by using high probe molecule densities on specially engineered surfaces that repel DNA adsorption from solution.  The rates of the DNA hybridization reaction were measured by recording ‘molecular movies’ where the formation of DNA duplexes coincides with the appearance of bright spot in the image. The spots appear as new duplexes are formed, and disappear as the duplexes dissociate. In the resulting movie, we observed hundreds of chemical reactions occur between individual molecules of DNA.  How long a spot remains in the movie reports how long it takes for the two DNA strands to dissociate.  Single-molecule imaging can also serve as an ultrasensitive analytical method, where counting individual bound DNA molecules on a capture surface enables detection of extremely low concentrations of target DNA in biological specimens at the level of only tens of molecules.

This research has generated new fundamental understanding of structural factors that influence the performance of DNA-based biosensors used in disease diagnosis. The program has developed new microscopy instrumentation for imaging the reactions of single molecules at surfaces and methods for detecting and counting of individual molecules, which represent the fundamental limits of quantitative chemical analysis. Through several collaborations, the research has impacted other areas of biological research, including imaging the clustering of protein receptors on cell surfaces and measuring the affinity of farnesylated proteins binding to lipid bilayer models of cell membranes. The team also demonstrated how nanometer-scale holes in thin metal films could enhance the fluorescence of biological molecules near the surface the metal film, another important advance in biosensor development.  Finally, the project introduced a novel method to measure the transport of molecules across lipid bilayer membranes and their accumulation into individual, micrometer-scale lipid vesicles for ultrasensitive sensitive detection. 

This project has also impacted teaching at a local high school, where microscopy methods were introduced for teaching students about chemical reactions on micrometer scale.  Students observed chemical reactions under the microscope and recorded movies of crystal growth or formation of small particles, using image analysis methods to determine the rates of reaction.  The amounts of chemicals needed for these exercises were 1,000-fold less than traditional experiments used in a classroom teaching, reducing the materials costs from hundreds of dollars to tens of cents.
